stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who underwent an open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the tibia three days ago. Review the patient's assessment findings below and determine which findings, if any, indicate the development of compartment syndrome. For each assessment finding, click to specify if it indicates a positive or negative finding for compartment syndrome.

rationale.correct: Compartment syndrome is characterized by the '6 Ps': pain (especially with passive movement), pallor, paresthesia, paralysis, pulselessness, and poikilothermia. Pain out of proportion to the injury and unrelieved by analgesics is a key early sign. Paresthesia is also an early finding. Pulselessness is a late sign, as is paralysis. Capillary refill is not a reliable indicator. Increased swelling contributes to increased pressure within the compartment.
rationale.incorrect: Pain controlled with analgesics suggests adequate pain management and does not point towards compartment syndrome. Intact motor function indicates no nerve damage or muscle ischemia at the time of the assessment. A palpable peripheral pulse indicates adequate arterial blood flow to the extremity, reducing the likelihood of compartment syndrome. Capillary refill less than 3 seconds is normal and does not suggest compartment syndrome. Although swelling can contribute to compartment syndrome, swelling alone is not necessarily indicative of compartment syndrome.
clinicalPearls: Early recognition of compartment syndrome is crucial to prevent permanent damage.
Pain out of proportion to the injury is the hallmark sign of compartment syndrome.
Assess the 6 Ps of compartment syndrome frequently, especially after orthopedic procedures.

questionTrap.trap: Students often focus only on pulselessness as a sign of compartment syndrome, overlooking earlier indicators like pain and paresthesia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the 6 Ps and prioritize the earlier signs, especially pain out of proportion to the injury and paresthesia.

mnemonic.title: 6 Ps
mnemonic.expansion: Pain, Pallor, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Pulselessness, Poikilothermia

reviewUnits.title: Compartment Syndrome
reviewUnits.content: Compartment syndrome is a condition in which increased pressure within a limited space compromises the circulation and function of the tissues within that space. It is a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention (fasciotomy) to prevent permanent muscle and nerve damage.

itemContext.sbar: 18:00 SBAR: Patient Jane Doe, post-ORIF tibia, POD #3. Pain 7/10 despite morphine. Swelling increased since AM. 17:00: Morphine 4mg IV given. 18:00: States pain unrelieved. Neurovascular checks q2h. Toes pink, capillary refill <3 sec. Pedal pulse palpable +2. Complains of numbness in the foot. Passive dorsiflexion of foot elicits extreme pain. Wound dressing clean, dry, intact. Vitals stable. Continue neurovascular checks. Monitor pain level and notify provider if worsening. Pt is anxious about pain.
